comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: Robert Burns Brown (1844-1916) was an Ohio native who fought in the Civil War, as an ordinary soldier. He was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for capturing a Confederate flag at the battle of Missionary Ridge in 1863. After the war he spent forty years working at the Zanesville Courier in Zanesville, Ohio. He joined the Civil War veterans fraternal organization, the Grand Army of the Republic, and eventually became its State Commander in Ohio, and then in 1906 the National Commander. It was from the G.A.R. that he received the honorary title of General. Here's a brief biography of him.
